results.title: Bound for Botany Bay
results.creator_credit: Jonathan King, John Dollar and First Fleet Films
results.brief_description: Using re-enactments and contemporary paintings and documents, this program addresses crime and punishment in 18th Century England, reasons for the colonisation of Australia, the fitting and sailing of the First Fleet and the arrival at Botany Bay and Port Jackson. The inclusion of a re-enactment of this arrival performed in modern Sydney, includes Aborigines protesting about the loss of their land rights. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Bound [DVD]
results.creator_credit: De Laurentiis Entertainment Group, Andrew Lazar, Stuart Boros, Andy Wachowski and Larry Wachowski
results.brief_description: A stylish and sexy noir thriller directed by the Wachowski Brothers. Corky (Gina Gershon) has just finished a stint in the slammer, and has been hired to renovate the apartment next door to Caeser (Joe Pantoliano), and his vampish girlfriend, Violet (Jennifer Tilly). Violet pursues Corky and they have an affair, which leads to them plotting to steal two million dollars of stashed Mafia money currently in Caeser’s custody. Can they pull off this daring theft, or will an unexpected twist in their otherwise flawless plan lead to their downfall?

results.title: Bound
results.creator_credit: Daniella Ortega, Serhat Caradee and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
A boy, a dead body, a relentless pursuit – it’s not what you see, it’s how you see it.
Bound is an urban tragedy about a boy who is mistakenly shot by the police. Jumping back and forth in time to reveal instincts colliding and lives unravelling in a world that rushes on regardless, this film is about what happens when you make all the wrong decisions for the right reasons.

results.title: Boudu Sauve des Eaux = Boudu Saved from Drowning
results.creator_credit: Michel Simon, Jean Gehret and Jean Renoir
results.brief_description:
Boudu, a rambling tramp, is taken into the middle-class household of a Parisian book seller after being rescued from the Seine. Boudu shows scant regard for bourgeois decorum. The humour is gently satirical and subversive rather than cutting, but is far from the original play’s affirmation of middle-class culture. Renoir’s use of long takes, camera movement, depth of field in loosely framed compositions with the continuous suggestion of a world beyond the frame, was the antithesis of the then developing Hollywood style of tight compositions and reverse angle cutting. Re-made as ‘Down and out in Beverly Hills’ by Paul Mazursky (1986). Further reading: Richard Boston. ‘Boudu saved from drowning’. London: BFI Publishing, 1994.

Credits: Producer, Jean Gehret, Michel Simon ; director, Jean Renoir ; writers, Jean Renoir, Robert Valentin ; photography, Marcel Lucien, George Asselin ; music, Raphael, Johann Strauss ; editor, Marguerite Houlle-Renoir, Suzanne de Troeye ; assistan
Cast: Michel Simon, Charles Granval, Marcelle Haina, Severine Lerczynska, Max Dalban, Jean Gehret, Jean Daste, Jacques Becker, Jane Pierson.

results.title: Bouddi
results.brief_description: A camera calligraphy of the coastal bush at Bouddi, NSW. This film springs from a strong attachment to the Australian bush landscape, an echo of the spirit of kinship that imbued the life of the Aboriginal tribes. The film is a camera calligraphy moving through the bush, capturing textures, surfaces, shadows and light, details of foliage and expanses of rocks and trees, insects and birds - it sees the bush in much the same way as Aboriginal hunters may have seen it, moving rapidly through it. The complexity of the images is repeated in the Aboriginal music, visuals and sounds forming a rhythmic pattern.

results.title: Bottles into dolls
results.creator_credit: Children's Library and Craft Movement, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description: Children learn to enjoy the art of making dolls from bottles, with plasticine. Imaginative use is made of a variety of materials at Brisbane’s Creative Leisure Centre. Costumes may be sewn, pinned or glued on to the figure and arms joined on with strips of plasticine. Finished figures are lined up and music-makers accompany the procession of completed dolls.

results.title: Bottle rocket
results.creator_credit: Colombia Pictures, Gracie Films, Polly Platt, Cynthia Hargrave and Wes Anderson
results.brief_description: Wes Anderson’s first feature film is a whimsical tale of three suburban misfits who attempt to commit the perfect robbery but end up in trouble with the local “Godfather” (played by James Caan). The conventions of the crime film are used as launch-pads for Anderson to construct a low-key but nevertheless deeply affecting romance about small-time lives and experience. The script, co-written by Anderson and star Owen Wilson, takes three friends on a mid-Western road trip in which Anthony (Luke Wilson) finds love with a Mexican immigrant, Inez (Lumi Cavazos); Dignan (Owen Wilson) plays out all his fantasies of being a master criminal; and Bob Mapplethorpe (Robert Musgrave) finds out that blood is, indeed, thicker than water. By finding beauty and comedy in the deeply suburban locales, Anderson is able to satirize the insularity of bourgeois American families and values without being condescending or cynical. The idiosyncratic, colourful and playful mise-en-scene of “Rushmore” and “The Royal Tenenbaums” is clearly evident in Anderson’s debut.

results.title: Botticelli: visions of beauty and violence
results.brief_description: Sandro Botticelli was one of the most popular and sought after artists of the Renaissance, renowned for his religious and mythological subjects and the beauty and sensuality of his painting. Working almost exclusively out of Florence, except for a stint in Rome to paint frescos for the Sistine Chapel, the bulk of his output was commissioned work for wealthy patrons such as the powerful Medici family. His friend and benefactor, Lorenzo di Pierfrancesco de’ Medici, commissioned Botticelli to provide illustrations for a copy of what has been viewed as the greatest ever work of Italian literature - Dante Alighieri’s Divine Comedy. Given complete artistic control over the project, Botticelli worked on the drawings between 1480 and 1495, and although they remain unfinished, they are viewed as some of the most enduring examples of his stylistic virtuosity. Working closely with Dante’s text, he painstakingly created illustrations for each section of the poem on fine goatskin parchment, expertly creating a visual interpretation of the poet’s epic passage through Hell, Purgatory and Paradise. A selection of art experts discuss the spiritual and political content, historical background and artistic execution of this work, and speculate on what drove this “explorer of beauty” to produce such a unique and animated accompaniment to Dante’s written account of the journey of the soul.

results.title: Both cultures
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Angel Towney and ACMI
results.brief_description: Angela Towney’s passion in life is for martial arts, for which she has competed around Australia and, she hopes, internationally. However, she acknowledges and pays homage to the influences that gave her the strength to achieve, her family and community in Wiradjuri country. Despite her father’s earlier troubles, his reform instilled a sense of pride and inner strength which allowed Angel to move beyond the community that she loved to follow her passion. Despite the difficulty of traversing two cultures, the introspection of the East and the Indigenous sense of community, her firey ambition and her innate love of her community and land, Angel recognises that she is enriched and embraced by both.
